title: Large font with solid letters close together
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131127055558im_/http:/typophile.com/files/firstfridaylogo_5545.jpg)

I'm trying to identify this font that I found on an old piece of design work. If we can identify it, we'd love to use it elsewhere. Thanks!

In case the image doesn't show up above - here's a link.

[https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B0swtBKbkzJhRmx1WjdyLVBHWGM/edit?usp=sha...](http://web.archive.org/web/20131127055558/https:/docs.google.com/file/d/0B0swtBKbkzJhRmx1WjdyLVBHWGM/edit?usp=sharing "https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B0swtBKbkzJhRmx1WjdyLVBHWGM/edit?usp=sharing")
author: benredmond

comments.content:
Reminds me of Eagle Bold -- the symbol of American recovery, drawn in 1933 by Morris Fuller Benton for the National Recovery Association -- with the counters blacked out. Metal Font by ATF. Digital font by Font Bureau: [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/eagle/](http://web.archive.org/web/20131127055558/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/eagle/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/eagle/")  
Don

Perfect match is [Nova Solid](http://web.archive.org/web/20131127055558/http:/www.dafont.com/nova-solid.font) by Billy Argel but as suggested by Don, you could do pretty much the same starting with any geometric black sans (Futura, Avant-Garde Gothic, Century Gothic...) and remove counters.
